message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: A survey on LLM-based multi-agent systems: workflow, infrastructure, and challenges
Paper Abstract: Abstract The pursuit of more intelligent and credible autonomous systems, akin to human society, has been a long-standing endeavor for humans. Leveraging the exceptional reasoning and planning capabilities of large language models (LLMs), LLM-based agents have been proposed and have achieved remarkable success across a wide array of tasks. Notably, LLM-based multi-agent systems (MAS) are considered a promising pathway towards realizing general artificial intelligence that is equivalent to or surpasses human-level intelligence. In this paper, we present a comprehensive survey of these studies, offering a systematic review of LLM-based MAS. Adhering to the workflow of LLM-based multi-agent systems, we synthesize a general structure encompassing five key components: profile, perception, self-action, mutual interaction, and evolution. This unified framework encapsulates much of the previous work in the field. Furthermore, we illuminate the extensive applications of LLM-based MAS in two principal areas: problem-solving and world simulation. Finally, we discuss in detail several contemporary challenges and provide insights into potential future directions in this domain.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the web search results for "Problem solving":

## Overview

Problem solving is the process of achieving a goal by overcoming obstacles, a frequent part of most activities.(no content)Problems range from simple personal tasks (e.g. how to turn on an appliance) to complex issues in business and technical fields.

## Key Characteristics

There are two different types of problems: ill-defined and well-defined; well-defined problems have specific end goals and clearly expected solutions, while ill-defined problems do not.(no content)There are many specialized problem-solving techniques and methods in fields such as science, engineering, business, medicine, mathematics, computer science, philosophy, and social organization.

## Problem-Solving Process

The process starts with problem finding and problem shaping, in which the problem is discovered and simplified; the next step is to generate possible solutions and evaluate them; finally a solution is selected to be implemented and verified.

## Mental Obstacles

Problem-solving impediments include confirmation bias, mental set, and functional fixedness.

## Research and Application

The mental techniques to identify, analyze, and solve problems are studied in psychology and cognitive sciences.(no content)Professionals such as lawyers, doctors, programmers, and consultants are largely problem solvers for issues that require technical skills and knowledge beyond general competence.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of multi-agent systems:

## Definition

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems research typically refers to software agents, but the agents could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.

## Capabilities and Applications

Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.(no content)Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

## Key Characteristics

Multi-agent systems have important characteristics including autonomy—where agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, autonomous—and decentralization, where no agent is designated as controlling.(no content)The systems also tend to prevent propagation of faults, self-recover and be fault tolerant, mainly due to the redundancy of components.

## Recent Developments

With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Related Research Areas

Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.

I've completed a web search for "Artificial Intelligence" and found comprehensive information from multiple sources. Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

Artificial intelligence is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.

## History and Development

Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.

## Research Goals and Approaches

The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.(no content)To reach these goals, AI researchers have adapted and integrated a wide range of techniques, including search and mathematical optimization, formal logic, artificial neural networks, and methods based on statistics, operations research, and economics.

## Current Focus

Some companies, such as OpenAI, Google DeepMind and Meta, aim to create artificial general intelligence (AGI) – AI that can complete virtually any cognitive task at least as well as a human.

## Applications

Artificial intelligence has been used in applications throughout industry and academia. Current applications span areas including architecture, contact centers, astronomy, military operations, and creative fields like music and visual art.

## Contemporary Challenges

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Autonomous systems"

Links: [{"title":"Autonomous system (Internet) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system_(Internet)"},{"title":"Wallenberg AI, Autonomous Systems and Software Program - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wallenberg_AI,_Autonomous_Systems_and_Software_Program"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"Autonomous system (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system_(mathematics)"},{"title":"List of driverless train systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_driverless_train_systems"},{"title":"Autonomous system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system"},{"title":"Annual Review of Control, Robotics, and Autonomous Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annual_Review_of_Control,_Robotics,_and_Autonomous_Systems"},{"title":"Autonomous decentralized system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_decentralized_system"},{"title":"Autonomous agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_agent"},{"title":"Autonomous robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot"}]

Based on the search results, "Autonomous systems" is a broad term that encompasses several different types of systems:

## Internet Autonomous Systems
An autonomous system (AS) is a collection of connected Internet Protocol (IP) routing prefixes under the control of one or more network operators on behalf of a single administrative entity or domain, that presents a common and clearly defined routing policy to the Internet.

## Autonomous Agents
An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence (AI) system that can perform complex tasks independently.(no content)An autonomous agent is a system situated within and a part of an environment that senses that environment and acts on it, over time, in pursuit of its own agenda and so as to effect what it senses in the future.

## Autonomous Robots
The most advanced systems now fuse information from various sensors for both localization (position) and navigation. Systems such as Motivity can rely on different sensors in different areas, depending upon which provides the most reliable data at the time, and can re-map a building autonomously.

## Autonomous Decentralized Systems
An autonomous decentralized system (or ADS) is a decentralized system composed of modules or components that are designed to operate independently but are capable of interacting with each other to meet the overall goal of the system. A unique feature of the ADS is that there is no central operating system or coordinator. Instead each subsystem manages its own functionality and its coordination with other subsystems.

## Research Field
The Annual Review of Control, Robotics, and Autonomous Systems is an annual peer-reviewed scientific journal published by Annual Reviews. In publication since 2018, the journal covers developments in the engineering of autonomous and semiautonomous systems through an annual volume of review articles.

Web search results for query: "Computer simulation"

Links: [{"title":"Computer simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_simulation"},{"title":"List of computer simulation software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_computer_simulation_software"},{"title":"Tierra (computer simulation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tierra_(computer_simulation)"},{"title":"Simulation (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulation_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Simulation hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulation_hypothesis"},{"title":"Simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulation"},{"title":"Crash simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crash_simulation"},{"title":"Brain simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brain_simulation"},{"title":"Computer-assisted surgery - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer-assisted_surgery"},{"title":"International Association for Mathematics and Computers in Simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Association_for_Mathematics_and_Computers_in_Simulation"}]

Here are the search results for "Computer simulation":

## Definition and Overview

Computer simulation is the running of a mathematical model on a computer, the model being designed to represent the behaviour of, or the outcome of, a real-world or physical system.(no content)By changing variables in the simulation, predictions may be made about the behaviour of the system.

## Applications

Computer simulations have become a useful tool for the mathematical modeling of many natural systems in physics (computational physics), astrophysics, climatology, chemistry, biology and manufacturing, as well as human systems in economics, psychology, social science, health care and engineering.(no content)It can be used to explore and gain new insights into new technology and to estimate the performance of systems too complex for analytical solutions.

## Historical Background

Computer simulation developed hand-in-hand with the rapid growth of the computer, following its first large-scale deployment during the Manhattan Project in World War II to model the process of nuclear detonation.

## Types of Simulations

A continuous dynamic simulation performs numerical solution of differential-algebraic equations or differential equations. Applications include flight simulators, construction and management simulation games, chemical process modeling, and simulations of electrical circuits.

The search results show that computer simulation is a fundamental tool across many scientific and engineering disciplines for modeling complex systems and phenomena.

Links: [{"title":"Logic for Programming, Artificial Intelligence and Reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_for_Programming,_Artificial_Intelligence_and_Reasoning"},{"title":"Reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reasoning_system"},{"title":"Automated reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_reasoning"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Knowledge representation and reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_representation_and_reasoning"},{"title":"Symbolic artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symbolic_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Commonsense reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonsense_reasoning"},{"title":"Commonsense knowledge (artificial intelligence) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonsense_knowledge_(artificial_intelligence)"},{"title":"Procedural reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Procedural_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Knowledge-based systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge-based_systems"}]

Here are the results from the web search on "Reasoning artificial intelligence":

## Overview

In information technology, a reasoning system is a software system that generates conclusions from available knowledge using logical techniques such as deduction and induction.(no content)Reasoning systems play an important role in the implementation of artificial intelligence and knowledge-based systems.

## Key Aspects

Automated reasoning helps produce computer programs that allow computers to reason completely or nearly completely automatically, and although it's considered a sub-field of artificial intelligence, it also has connections with theoretical computer science and philosophy.(no content)The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.

## Types of Reasoning Systems

The most developed subareas of automated reasoning are automated theorem proving (and the less automated but more pragmatic subfield of interactive theorem proving) and automated proof checking.(no content)Knowledge representation goes hand in hand with automated reasoning because one of the main purposes of explicitly representing knowledge is to be able to reason about that knowledge, to make inferences, assert new knowledge, etc.

## Commonsense Reasoning

In artificial intelligence, commonsense reasoning is a human-like ability to make presumptions about the type and essence of ordinary situations humans encounter every day, including judgments about the nature of physical objects, taxonomic properties, and peoples' intentions.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Planning algorithm"

Links: [{"title":"Automated planning and scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_planning_and_scheduling"},{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning"},{"title":"Graphplan - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graphplan"},{"title":"Real-time path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_path_planning"},{"title":"D* - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D*"},{"title":"Any-angle path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Any-angle_path_planning"},{"title":"Partial-order planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partial-order_planning"},{"title":"Lifelong Planning A* - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lifelong_Planning_A*"},{"title":"A* search algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A*_search_algorithm"},{"title":"Theta* - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theta*"}]

## Planning Algorithm - Search Results

I found comprehensive information about planning algorithms. Here's an overview of the key concepts:

### What is Automated Planning?

Automated planning and scheduling, sometimes denoted as simply AI planning, is a branch of artificial intelligence that concerns the realization of strategies or action sequences, typically for execution by intelligent agents, autonomous robots and unmanned vehicles.

### The Planning Problem

Given a description of the possible initial states of the world, a description of the desired goals, and a description of a set of possible actions, the planning problem is to synthesize a plan that is guaranteed (when applied to any of the initial states) to generate a state which contains the desired goals.

### Types of Planning Approaches

Several major planning algorithm categories emerged from the search results:

1. **Classical Planning** - Since the initial state is known unambiguously, and all actions are deterministic, the state of the world after any sequence of actions can be accurately predicted, and plans can be defined as sequences of actions.

2. **Graphplan** - Graphplan is an algorithm for automated planning developed by Avrim Blum and Merrick Furst in 1995. Graphplan takes as input a planning problem expressed in STRIPS and produces, if one is possible, a sequence of operations for reaching a goal state.

3. **Partial-Order Planning** - Partial-order planning is an approach to automated planning that maintains a partial ordering between actions and only commits ordering between actions when forced to. A partial-order plan specifies all actions that must be taken, but specifies an ordering between actions only where needed.

4. **Motion Planning** - Motion planning, also path planning, is a computational problem to find a sequence of valid configurations that moves the object from the source to destination.

The search results show that planning algorithms are fundamental to robotics, autonomous vehicles, and various AI applications, with domain-independent planners able to solve problems across multiple domains.

Web search results for query: "Large Language Model"

Links: [{"title":"Large language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Large_language_models"},{"title":"List of large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_large_language_models"},{"title":"Language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_model"},{"title":"Llama (language model) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LLaMA"},{"title":"BERT (language model) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BERT_(language_model)"},{"title":"ELMo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ELMo"},{"title":"PaLM - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PaLM"},{"title":"Transformer (machine learning model) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transformer_(machine_learning_model)"},{"title":"GPT-3 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GPT-3"}]

I've performed a web search for "Large Language Model" and found comprehensive information about this topic. Here's what I found:

## Definition

A large language model (LLM) is a language model trained with self-supervised machine learning on a vast amount of text, designed for natural language processing tasks, especially language generation.

## Key Characteristics

These models consist of billions to trillions of parameters and operate as general-purpose sequence models, generating, summarizing, translating, and reasoning over text.(no content)The largest and most capable LLMs are generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and provide the core capabilities of modern chatbots.

## Training and Capabilities

LLMs can be fine-tuned for specific tasks or guided by prompt engineering. These models acquire predictive power regarding syntax, semantics, and ontologies inherent in human language corpora, but they also inherit inaccuracies and biases present in the data they are trained on.

## Architecture

As of 2024, the largest and most capable models are all based on the transformer architecture.(no content)Since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes.

## Applications

LLMs represent a significant new technology in their ability to generalize across tasks with minimal task-specific supervision, enabling capabilities like conversational agents, code generation, knowledge retrieval, and automated reasoning.

LLMs can be fine-tuned for specific tasks or guided by prompt engineering. These models acquire predictive power regarding syntax, semantics, and ontologies inherent in human language corpora, but they also inherit inaccuracies and biases present in the data they are trained on.

## Architecture

As of 2024, the largest and most capable models are all based on the transformer architecture.(no content)Since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes.

## Applications

LLMs represent a significant new technology in their ability to generalize across tasks with minimal task-specific supervision, enabling capabilities like conversational agents, code generation, knowledge retrieval, and automated reasoning.

message_text:
Excellent! All tasks have been completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** This paper is a **survey** - it presents a comprehensive literature review of LLM-based multi-agent systems, explicitly stating "we present a comprehensive survey of these studies, offering a systematic review of LLM-based MAS."

**Triples Extracted:** I identified and documented 8 key triples from the paper's title and abstract:

1. **Large language model** (artifact) - The core technology enabling agent capabilities
2. **Multi-agent system** (concept) - The central architecture being surveyed
3. **Artificial intelligence** (concept) - The broader field context
4. **Autonomous agent** (concept) - Individual entities in the systems
5. **Reasoning system** (concept) - Provides logical foundations for decision-making
6. **Automated planning and scheduling** (method) - Key agent capability
7. **Problem solving** (task) - Principal application area explicitly mentioned
8. **Computer simulation** (task) - World simulation application area explicitly mentioned

**Validation:** All triples have been validated successfully with correct Wikipedia URLs, proper entity types, appropriate relations ("uses" for a survey paper), and meaningful relevance descriptions.

The triples_output.json file has been updated and passes all validation checks.

Sources:
- [Large language model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model)
- [Multi-agent system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system)
- [Artificial intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence)
- [Autonomous agent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_agent)
